prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Existing Definitions of Confidential Business Information and Trade Secrets

para.paratext: Any information of a business, commercial, industrial, strategic, technical or scientific nature may merit legal protection. Such information may consist of a formula, a recipe, a process or a mechanism. In form, the information may be a document, a customer list, data, plans or drawings. The subject-matter may relate to high technology such as computers or telecommunications, or simply to a company's business, financial or marketing plans.[1]

While the Canadian judiciary has historically relied upon the leading English cases in this area of the law, the courts have not hesitated to apply American authorities, including the definition contained in the Restatement of the Law of Torts.[2] Generally, Canadian courts have been willing to rely on American precedent where there is an absence of Canadian, English, or other Commonwealth authorities;[3] like fact situations;[4] comparable underlying legal principles at issue;[5] or similar industry practice throughout North America.[6]

Until recently, American courts[7] relied upon the definition of trade secrets set forth by the Committee on Torts of the American Law Institute in the Restatement of the Law of Torts,[8] first published in 1939, which stated that a trade secret would consist of information used in business that gave the business an opportunity to obtain an advantage over competitors that did not know the information.

The Restatement of the Law of Torts, while generally offering a broad definition of “trade secrets”, took a somewhat restricted view of certain other types of business information. For example, it excluded information relating to “single or ephemeral events” in the conduct of a business. In other words, to be capable of protection, information had to be “used continuously in the operation of the business”. Examples of information sometimes considered to be of a transitory nature falling outside the scope of protection included a secret bid, the salary of key employees, contemplated investments, or a key announcement date.[9] However, in today's competitive global economy, it becomes difficult to justify the exclusion of such potentially crucial information from the definition of a trade secret. Maintenance of secrecy with regard to secret bids, the compensation of key employees, corporate investment strategy, policy changes, marketing strategies and corporate timetables or announcements is of paramount interest to the modern business.[10] Information regarding a competitor's bid could result in underbidding and a huge contract. Knowledge of compensation structures and details can make it significantly easier to entice away a competitor's key employees. In general, information regarding a competitor's strategies and the timing for implementation will offer a significant business advantage. Nevertheless, at times, American courts have declined to adopt a broader view of the business information worthy of protection.[11] Ironically, though, the Restatement of the Law of Torts, in a subsequent section, provided for the potential protection of any “information about another's business”.[12]

As a result of the many uncertainties in this area of the law, the Commissioners on Uniform State Law adopted the Uniform Trade Secrets Act[13] in 1979. Over the course of the intervening years, 40 state legislatures in the United States have adopted this Act, which defines “trade secret” as follows:
1(4) “Trade Secret” means information, including a formula, pattern, compilation, program, device, method, technique or process that:

derives independent economic value, actual or potential, from not being generally known to, and not being readily ascertainable by proper means by, other persons who can obtain economic value from its disclosure or use, and
is the subject of efforts that are reasonable under the circumstances to maintain its secrecy.

As a result of (1) the use of the generic term “information”; (2) the addition of the word “potential” to modify “economic value”; and (3) the elimination of the notion of “continuous use”, the broader definition in the uniform legislation appears to be wide enough to cover all information that is secret and valuable in nature. To date, the decided cases under the Uniform Trade Secrets Act have confirmed that most business information can, assuming that the secrecy and value elements exist, qualify as a trade secret.[14]

Given the past difficulties in defining confidential information, treating the term “trade secret” as synonymous with “confidential business information” would help to eliminate some of the doctrinal uncertainty in this area of the law. It might also eliminate the need for lists that attempt to comprehensively set forth each and every type of information that qualifies as a trade secret.

The authors of this text recommend the creation of a very broad definition such as that included in the proposed Canadian Uniform Trade Secrets Act propounded by the Institute of Law Research and Reform.[15] The Institute's report listed four basic requirements for information to qualify for protection: it must be used in business, not be generally known, have economic value from being unknown, and be subject to reasonable efforts to maintain it in secrecy. While acknowledging traditional descriptions that include such things as formulae, patterns, compilations, programs, methods, techniques or processes, the broader definition provides for a practical and functional approach to the analysis of business information. Whatever the definition, the authors also recommend adding a phrase such as “or any other information” to ensure that the definition would not become bogged down by technical categories.

While the definitions already discussed have had some influence, the Canadian courts have, to date, largely formulated their own criteria for defining confidential business information. Typically, the judiciary has focused its analysis on the nature of the information and the nature of the relationship between the relevant parties, including the specific circumstances that resulted in disclosure. Some authorities have emphasized the nature of the information, while others have emphasized the nature of the relevant relationship.

Finally, it is important to note that case law definitions and the implied duties resulting from the principles of equity and tort law can be modified by a contractual term dealing expressly or by implication with confidentiality.[16]
See the description in A.E. Turner, The Law of Trade Secrets (London: Sweet & Maxwell, 1962), p. 4.
